texts.definition: Diegetic persons in game worlds that are not controlled by players.
markups: <style="Definition">Diegetic persons in game worlds that are not controlled by players.</style>

Note: the use of characters in this pattern and the pattern named Characters differs. Here, the usage of character complies to the common usage in the gaming community of referring to the graphical representation of a person in the game world (a sort of non-player version of the Avatar patterns). Although the common usage may also often imply the presence of the Agents and Characters patterns, this is not necessary and not presumed when used here.
Note: the abbreviation NPCs is very common for Non-Player Characters and is used here as well.

Many games depict fictional worlds populated with people of more or less human qualities. Since rarely all of these are controlled by players, by necessity those not under player influence need to be <style="CurrentLink">Non-Player Characters</style>. These can range from still dummies to highly advanced AI systems or puppets for game masters but all have in common that their fate and ability to influence the outcome of a game is not on the same level as that controlled by players.

Although not that interesting as personalities, early arcade games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> can be said to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> since each of them was given some unique feature. Here the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> fill the role of adversaries and this can be done even if they are not directly presented in the game, since they can be implied through how they affect gameplay, e.g. by driving the other cars in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Need%20for%20Speed%20series">Need for Speed series</link></style>.

Many games use <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> for several different reasons - it is quite common to have some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> provide specific actions such as trading or giving quests and have other <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> only be enemies. Examples of this include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thief%20series">Thief series</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empires%20&%20Allies">Empires & Allies</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Non-Player Characters</style> that are never encountered in the game worlds but only appear in popup windows and neighbor lists. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Black%20&%20White%20series">Black & White series</link></style> uses <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> to provide mortal beings that can be caused to fear or idolize the player's god. An additional use of these <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> is that they can provide a means for game world in single-player games to have a population, something which can also be used to increase the population of multiplayer games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> and to avoid making it feel completely unpeopled.

The later instances in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> that have daily routines, go through the actions of eating and sleeping, and have short conversations with other <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style>. They also have allegiances to various social groups and will come to the defend of other members of these groups if they are attacked. The games in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fable">Fable</link></style> series function similarly. Although these <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> have complex behavior, they are only on part of the gameplay in these games. In contrast, the interactive drama <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fa%C3%A7ade">Façade</link></style> focuses nearly entirely on interacting with the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> Grace and Trip, and observing how they interact with each other.

Sometimes the issues of whether a diegetic person is an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style> or not depends on the play mode, and can be mostly a subjective opinion. For example, when playing the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> with other players it is quite clear that they are not <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> but when playing one of these games alone offline they are more likely to be treated as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style>. Playing alone online is more unclear since other players may join but one does not know that until after the fact (one could argue that the designers see them as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> in this case since the server shuts down if one disconnects). Although example of a borderline case is in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style>; any Sim in the active household can be controlled by a player but does not need to be, and Sims from other households created by the same player may come for a visit but do this as pure <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style>.

Non-Player Characters are fundamentally diegetic Game Elements. Their most important characteristics are which role they play in relation to the players and the Game World they inhabit, and this can be modulated through their appearance and disappearance through Game Element Insertion and Game Element Removal. Since some NPCs mainly have roles as extras, in fact being Self-Service Kiosks that serve as Helpers, this somewhat paradoxically mean that it is not necessary for all Non-Player Characters to be Generic Adversaries or Characters. Instead, it may be more important that they can recognized during gameplay for what they are, which for NPCs that are supposed to individually distinguishable probably means that they need to have Diegetically Outstanding Features. The lack of Character does not mean that they cannot play essential parts of Narration Structures, they can perform these roles through Cutscenes. In fact, through the use of Cutscenes NPCs can be part of games even if they rarely or never can be perceived or interacted with in the actual Game World. One specific example of this is Browser in many of the Super Mario series, he is typically encountered early during gameplay and then several times throughout the game through Cutscenes but is only possible to interact with him as a Boss Monster during the final fight of the game.

A primary choice when designing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> is whether they should have agency within the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. Making them <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> is typically achieved through the use of <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, but can sometimes be done through <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style> (especially in games with <style="Link"><link="pervasive-gameplay">Pervasive Gameplay</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Prosopopeia">Prosopopeia</link></style>).  An additional option to adjust the level of agency is to consider giving the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> <style="Link"><link="initiative">Initiative</link></style>, although this may lead to a loss of <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style>. When <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> have agency, they can take the opposing roles of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> (and <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>) or supporting ones of <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> by giving them <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> respectively. By using these options, <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> can easily be modified to provide <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>. The role of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> can make it possible to allow activities requiring many participants, e.g. <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style> competitions, in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> although in contrast to <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> this is typically done as part of some <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Game</link></style> where the player can improve <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>. That being said, in many cases it is not necessary to consider the possible <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style> aspects of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> - it is sufficient to simple see them as <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>. One example of this is as opponents that make <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals more difficult; in this case the primary concerns is how the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can move in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and perceived events that take place there. The use of <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> can be predetermined by <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> of successfully completing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gain%20Allies">Gain Allies</link></style> goals, or be possible to create as <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style> during the initial set-up of games. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> used as <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> can also affect <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> by having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Linked%20Destinies">Linked Destinies</link></style> or being the cause of <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> for players. The options players have in interacting with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can through these means easily be made into <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>.

Even without agency <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can provide many different types of opportunities for interaction with handling <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style> and the assignment and adjudication of <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> being common. Likewise, they can be important parts of goals through being the senders and receivers in <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style> goals, being the objectives of <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guide%20and%20Protect">Guide and Protect</link></style> goals, by making up the pool of possible candidates in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Match-Making">Match-Making</link></style> goals, or the receivers of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Binding%20Promises">Binding Promises</link></style> to make <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goals</link></style> diegetically present in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. When the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> only can perform these actions (due to not having agency) they are in principle <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style> for the players.

Providing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> is related to the choice of giving them agency but can be done independently and opens up for many design choices, e.g. providing them with <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> without agency can provide <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> but does so without forcing players to become reactive. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/ELIZA">ELIZA</link></style> can be argued to be an example of this although this is achieved through a set of response rules rather than through abstract characteristics. Adventure games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Secret%20of%20Monkey%20Island%20series">The Secret of Monkey Island series</link></style> and the first instances in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> can also be said to do this, but through <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> in this case. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> which are <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> typically provide even more <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, as for example found in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> and later installments of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>.

Being able to engage in <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> is a common functionality. This may be as simple as a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Canned%20Text%20Responses">Canned Text Responses</link></style> to show that they have nothing important to say (but makes finding <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> with something to say a form of exploration goal) but can also be the primary type of interaction (as in, for example, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/ELIZA">ELIZA</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fa%C3%A7ade">Façade</link></style>). Combining <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style> with <style="CurrentLink">Non-Player Characters</style> does create a powerful medium for <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> but these are only as powerful as the parsing ability of the system and its ability to generate specific responses. Besides allowing <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> to unfold, typically uses of <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> include: giving, supporting or finishing <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> or other <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goals</link></style>; providing services such as teaching <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>; or giving <style="Link"><link="gossip">Gossip</link></style> that either indicate <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style> or shows <style="Link"><link="memory-important-events">Memory of Important Events</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-world-changes">Persistent Game World Changes</link></style>). By making <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> part of <style="Link"><link="main-quests">Main Quests</link></style> game designs can guarantee that players will have encountered them if they have completed a game.  For games supporting more <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> through the use of <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style>, the specific challenges of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/False%20Accusations">False Accusations</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Brokering">Brokering</link></style> and the goal of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maintaining%20Lies">Maintaining Lies</link></style> are possible.

One of the uses of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> is to create <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> that players can interact with or become members of. The goal to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gain%20Allies">Gain Allies</link></style> can also be modified so that successfully completing it results in a whole <style="Link"><link="factions">Faction</link></style> becomes an ally rather than a single <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style>, and actions towards individual <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can easily become <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> since they can affect a player possibilities to interact with a whole <style="Link"><link="factions">Faction</link></style>. Individual <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can has special statuses in these <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> by being <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Gatekeepers">Social Gatekeepers</link></style>, competitors in situations of <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, or by secretly being <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style> setup to commit <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> at some point. Having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, or at least implicit ones through a willingness to talk to each other, make it possible to modify many of the gameplay possibilities of <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> to be possible through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eavesdropping">Eavesdropping</link></style> (possibly requiring the completion of <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> goals).

More generally, NPCs can be used to make the culture and social norms of Game Worlds part of the gameplay through Diegetic Social Norms. This make it possible that Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences, e.g. assaulting people in civilized areas provoke attacks from the law authorities as in the Assassin's Creed or the Elder Scrolls series. While this can regulate which actions are not socially acceptable, and when, by the NPCs, Diegetic Social Maintenance can be used to make it socially unacceptable to not perform certain actions according to some rule set. All of these can be applied on both general levels and on Faction levels, creating more Complex Gameplay by making players need to handle competing and possible incompatible social rules.

Note that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> do not actually need to be able to perform actions that change the game state, and more specifically players do not have to able to interact with them at all. The core of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> are their role in a <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structure</link></style>, and as such they can exist only as <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> or only be seen through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>. One example of this can be found in the <style="Link"><link="massively-single-player-online-games">Massively Single-Player Online Games</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empires%20&%20Allies">Empires & Allies</link></style> - here the <style="CurrentLink">Non-Player Characters</style> are only seen in the <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style> of the games even though players can visit some of their <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style>.

Since <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> typically should be populated with inhabitants, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> are in many cases required for them to have <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. The exception is when these inhabitants can be treated as one or several groups but without individual differences within the group(s) - in this case the use of <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> suffice. Since <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> are supposed to be distinct from <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can be a necessity in this case as well.

One design goal with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can be that they should be believable as humans or self-aware individuals with the same emotional and social responses as those associated with humans. This can be rephrased as the goal of making players take an intentional stance towards the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> when anticipating their actions. This may be an unreachable goal using current technology but temporary successes are possible (most famously shown already with the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/ELIZA">ELIZA</link></style> program in the 1960s). The suggestions below provide options that designers can apply depending on how much effort they wish to put into placing people in an intentional stance and keeping them there.

A basic requirement for this to be possible is that the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> is in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> so that it has a space to act within (which may be the real world for games using <style="Link"><link="real-world-gameplay-spaces">Real World Gameplay Spaces</link></style>). How they behave in this world needs to have <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> for the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style> to fit there, and this may require <style="Link"><link="awareness-surroundings">Awareness of Surroundings</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="context-dependent-reactions">Context Dependent Reactions</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="memory-important-events">Memory of Important Events</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> partially exhibit these characteristics: they make comments about their surroundings and commonly known world events but ignore corpses in their immediate proximity.

A second basic requirement is that they are <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. As mentioned earlier, this is typically done through <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> but can in some cases also be done through <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style>. Examples of ways to increase players impression of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> agency (in contrast to simply making them more powerful) includes providing them with <style="Link"><link="initiative">Initiative</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="own-agenda">Own Agendas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competing%20for%20Attention">Competing for Attention</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Barge-In">Barge-In</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="unpredictable-behavior">Unpredictable Behavior</link></style>. The four first of these are present in the interactive drama <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fa%C3%A7ade">Façade</link></style> while the last one may result from the system's inability to parse player input - this does not necessary need to be a bad thing and is part of the reason why <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/ELIZA">ELIZA</link></style> works (in combination with using <style="Link"><link="ambiguous-responses">Ambiguous Responses</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Others%20fortune%20affects%20own%20Mood">Others fortune affects own Mood</link></style> is related both to having <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> in response to what happens in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> and to having agency - it can be expressed through how <style="Link"><link="memory-important-events">Memory of Important Events</link></style> are made visible or through attacking those that threaten others in one's <style="Link"><link="factions">Faction</link></style>. For games striving for <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>, it can be important to provide each <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style>, or at least for the most important ones, with an <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style> to avoid risking that players take the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> experiences as predetermined and thereby not necessary to involve oneself in. Games using <style="Link"><link="generic-adversaries">Generic Adversaries</link></style> to create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can for the discussed reason here want to make them at least have different appearances and possibly varied <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style> even if they are <style="Link"><link="generic-adversaries">Generic Adversaries</link></style>.

Another aspect of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> is how player can interact with them. That one cannot interact in all the ways people can interact with each other in the real world is typically accepted just as one cannot perform all the actions possible in the real world. However, when there are inconsistencies in that one can perform certain actions towards some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> but not others problems can arise (the same goes when some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can perform actions and others cannot but diegetically should be able to). For example, it is not possible to attack <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> of your faction in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>. Although this might be argued to be <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> to preserve the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> it can also be seen as limiting players' <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and limiting the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> of players by making the <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> of their <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style> difficult or impossible. However, allowing this can ruin <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> and lead to <style="Link"><link="unpredictable-behavior">Unpredictable Behavior</link></style> in the eyes of other players. Another example of this is the inconsistency in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> regarding if it is possible to kill children or not. Besides the moral issues related to these types of design questions, typically trying to acknowledge these possible actions requires more resources in the development of game and may only be worthwhile if one if aiming to support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sandbox%20Gameplay">Sandbox Gameplay</link></style>. Having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> provide <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> is also related to their <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> and can make them <style="Link"><link="resource-sources">Resource Sources</link></style>.

There is actually another, even more basic, aspect of making <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> to have <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. This is that their representations should mimic their states as appropriate for the setting (a form of <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>). In games like the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> this may be that the Bob-ombs <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> flash and sound before exploding while in games with high granularity in their <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> system such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> this may require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Visual%20Body%20Damage">Visual Body Damage</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dissectible%20Bodies">Dissectible Bodies</link></style>. In games which simulate <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Sports">Sports</link></style>, it might even be appropriate to let <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> perform <style="Link"><link="ragequitting">Ragequitting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sid%20Meier's%20SimGolf">Sid Meier's SimGolf</link></style> is an example of this in that the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> opponents one is playing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Golf">Golf</link></style> against can give up and leave an ongoing game if their mood turns sour.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tutorial%20Neighbors">Tutorial Neighbors</link></style> are a special kind of <style="CurrentLink">Non-Player Characters</style> which have some characteristics of passive players. They are used as ersatz <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="massively-single-player-online-games">Massively Single-Player Online Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ravenwood%20Fair">Ravenwood Fair</link></style> where they provide initial places for <style="Link"><link="visits">Visits</link></style> and give players <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>.

The amount of interaction available with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can easily become overwhelming. Although breaking <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, this is often solved through the use of <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> to provide separate interfaces (and modes of play) for activities such as <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> of the allowed <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style>. The cost of this for <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> is making <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Barge-In">Barge-In</link></style> more disruptive and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gameplay%20Integrated%20Conversations">Gameplay Integrated Conversations</link></style> impossible.

Many of the notes above regarding <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> and diegetic aspects are also strongly related to <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> in games. This is quite natural since having people convey information or emotions is one of the most flexible ways to provide information and many stories revolve around social relations and  - <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can be a way for designers to do both these things and typically so through <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> as well as preconstructing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> or events related to them as <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. For games basing their <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> on a <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structure</link></style>, this is especially likely to be useful since information to a player has to be provided to that player's <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatar</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style>. The use of <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can be powerful narrative devices besides their impact on gameplay.

Since the creation of any <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style> implies a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> it consists in, have a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style> either requires a more fully developed <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> or creates one anyway but without <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. Further, since the core of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> is to present a diegetic person it is at odds with the <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> patterns, both because <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> typically have some individual variation and that they by definition are not controlled by players.

While giving <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> introduces <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> and possibly <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> in games, <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style> can be achieved through giving them <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> instead. One example of this is that situations where players have <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> can lead to them having to engage in <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>. Agency of any type in connection to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> automatically provide <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> and typically leads to <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> (except when used in conjunction with <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> when it instead can provide <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>). This complexity is typically multiplied by the level of detail put into the <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> connected to each <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPC</link></style>, if any.
